title: Schrödinger Equation
summary: Central equation of quantum mechanics describing the time evolution of quantum systems.
long_explanation: The Schrödinger equation is the fundamental equation of quantum mechanics. The time-dependent form describes how the quantum state of a physical system changes over time. The time-independent form (eigenvalue equation) yields stationary states and energy eigenvalues.
common_pitfalls: Confusing time-dependent and time-independent forms; not recognizing that solutions must be square-integrable.

faq.q: What is the difference between time-dependent and time-independent Schrödinger equations?
faq.a: The time-dependent equation describes full quantum dynamics; the time-independent equation applies to stationary states with definite energy.

mastery_checklist: Derive TISE from TDSE for stationary states
Solve TISE for particle in a box

title: Hartree-Fock Theory
summary: Mean-field approximation for electronic structure treating electrons in average field of all other electrons.
long_explanation: Hartree-Fock (HF) theory approximates the many-electron wavefunction as a single Slater determinant. Each electron moves in the average field of all other electrons. The method is self-consistent (SCF) and variationally optimizes molecular orbitals. HF neglects electron correlation.
common_pitfalls: Assuming HF captures all physics; ignoring correlation energy; poor convergence for difficult systems.

faq.q: Why does Hartree-Fock fail for strongly correlated systems?
faq.a: HF uses a single determinant and mean-field approximation, missing static and dynamic electron correlation.

mastery_checklist: Derive HF equations from variational principle
Recognize when post-HF methods are needed

title: Basis Sets
summary: Mathematical functions used to expand molecular orbitals in quantum chemistry calculations.
long_explanation: Basis sets are collections of functions (typically Gaussian or Slater-type orbitals) used to represent molecular orbitals. Larger, more complete basis sets yield more accurate results but increase computational cost. Common families: STO-3G (minimal), 6-31G (split-valence), cc-pVXZ (correlation-consistent).
common_pitfalls: Using minimal basis sets for quantitative work; ignoring basis set superposition error (BSSE); not checking convergence with basis size.

faq.q: What is the difference between minimal and split-valence basis sets?
faq.a: Minimal (e.g., STO-3G) uses one basis function per atomic orbital. Split-valence (e.g., 6-31G) uses multiple functions for valence orbitals, improving flexibility.

mastery_checklist: Choose appropriate basis set for calculation type

title: Electron Correlation
summary: Quantum mechanical effects arising from instantaneous electron-electron interactions beyond mean-field approximation.
long_explanation: Electron correlation is the difference between exact electronic energy and Hartree-Fock energy. Dynamic correlation arises from instantaneous Coulomb repulsion; static correlation from near-degeneracies. Post-HF methods (MP2, CCSD, CASSCF) recover correlation energy.
common_pitfalls: Confusing dynamic and static correlation; using single-reference methods for multi-reference problems.

faq.a: The energy difference between the exact non-relativistic energy and the Hartree-Fock energy.

title: Density Functional Theory
summary: Quantum mechanical method using electron density rather than wavefunction as fundamental variable.
long_explanation: DFT is based on Hohenberg-Kohn theorems: ground state energy is a unique functional of electron density. Kohn-Sham formulation maps interacting system to non-interacting system with same density. Exchange-correlation functional approximation determines accuracy.
common_pitfalls: Treating DFT as ab initio method; blindly trusting functional predictions without validation; incorrect functional choice for problem type.

faq.a: The functional capturing quantum exchange and correlation effects in DFT. It is approximated (LDA, GGA, hybrid, etc.).
